conclusion: To determine when the object's velocity is at its maximum, we need to analyze the given acceleration-time graph.

The acceleration is the rate of change of velocity, so the velocity will be at its maximum when the acceleration is zero and is increasing (i.e., the acceleration is positive and increasing, or negative and decreasing).
From t = 0 to t = 1 s, the acceleration is +2 m/s^2.
From t = 1 s to t = 3 s, the acceleration is decreasing linearly from +2 m/s^2 to -2 m/s^2.
From t = 3 s to t = 4 s, the acceleration is -2 m/s^2.
The velocity is maximum when the acceleration is zero and is changing from positive to negative.
From the graph, the acceleration is zero at t = 2 s, which is the point where the velocity is at its maximum.
To confirm, we calculate the velocity at t = 2 s by integrating the acceleration function.
The area under the acceleration-time graph gives the change in velocity.
The area of the rectangle from t = 0 to t = 1 s is 2 x 1 = 2 m/s.
The area of the triangle from t = 1 to t = 2 s is 1/2 x 1 x 2 = 1 m/s.
Since the object starts from rest, the velocity at t = 2 s is 3 m/s.
After t = 2 s, the acceleration is negative, so the velocity will start to decrease.
Therefore, the velocity is at its maximum at t = 2 s.
